Comment: I'm annotating this game because of statistical felicity rather than technical merit, though there is a lesson for us all at the end.  id=aramis is one of my buddies and my record against him now stands at P16 W11 L5 since I lost the return game in this League D2 match.
A relatively uncommon but perfectly OK response to the Najdorf.

6...e6 would have transposed into the Scheveningen.  I played 6...e5 on principle.  Looking it up in Nunn and Gallagher's 'The Complete Najdorf: Modern Lines', I find that this is the main line response.
But this is described as a sideline, compared with 7. Nb3.
Black immediately covers the hole at d5.
?! Nunn gives 8. Ng5 Qc7 9. Nxe6 fxe6 10. 0-0 Be7 11. f4 exf4 12. Bxf4 giving a slight edge for White
Now we're out of Nunn's book, though playing moves that are generally typical of such an opening.
White takes aim at b6, an approach that has caused me problems in the past.
Here it comes ...
Here it comes ...
White seizes the opportunity to secure the advantage of the two bishops.  Black cannot prevent it.
White seizes the opportunity to secure the advantage of the two bishops.  Black cannot prevent it.
The central doubled pawns aren't too disastrous because the mobile d-pawn should enable Black to sort them out and the f-file is now half-open in his favour.
The central doubled pawns aren't too disastrous because the mobile d-pawn should enable Black to sort them out and the f-file is now half-open in his favour.
The central doubled pawns aren't too disastrous because the mobile d-pawn should enable Black to sort them out and the f-file is now half-open in his favour.
Black prepares either to occupy c4 or advance the d-pawn
Black prepares either to occupy c4 or advance the d-pawn
White responds by threatening to win a pawn on b5
Black, probably wrongly, decides that the most urgent task is to sort out his central pawns and threaten a fork from d4.  This loses material rather than gains it.
Now both d5 and b5 are targeted by overwhelming odds.

Now White is 2 pawns up and his Q is dominating the board.

White gives up the b-pawn to protect f2.
Now I had visions of Bxf2+ with a discovered attack on White's Q but couldn't find a way to force White to undefend his Q.
